Christopher gray visits a very special
library I'm Christopher gray
architectural historian and streetscapes
columnist for The New York Times every
block I walk down I'm looking for an odd
detail a strange building New York's
little mysteries it's my job to solve
them the city and its architecture is my
beat in 1906 the brilliant taciturn
banker J Pierpont Morgan built this
treasure house for the books and
manuscripts he had amassed like a vacuum
cleaner rolling back and forth across
Europe now one of New York's great
museums the Morgan Library is just
finishing an interior restoration of its
remarkable rooms
his architect Charles McKim took four
years to design and finish this perfect
little Tennessee marble gym it must have
been a glorious day for Morgan when he
could finally bring his precious
collection in debris the holy air was
little temple it includes illuminated
manuscripts drafts by authors like Blake
PO Zola and Dickens Gutenberg Bibles and
a life mask of George Washington
Morgan finished his library in 1906 and
in this crimson room study he could
smoke cigars play solitaire and enjoy
his favorite possessions which he kept
in his safe in late 1907 a financial
panic threatened to wreck the entire
country
Morgan summoned 50 leading bankers to
this room and told them they needed to
raise 25 million dollars between them
and walked out the door by 4:15 in the
morning no progress had been made Morgan
came back in with an agreement for each
of them to sign sharing the cost no one
moved he walked over to the first man
and said here is the place and here is
the pen everyone signed
and then these great bronze doors were
opened Morgan had had the key in his
pocket they had all been locked in
six years later JP Morgan died his
casket came out these same bronze doors
Frank Vanderlip head of National City

is at half-mast this building is his

professor tackles ankle sprains with the
balancing act ankle sprains are the the
most common injury that happened in
people who exercise or participate in
sport and a lot of people think that no
as long as I can walk or even get back
to running without a limp that they
don't have a long standing problem but
once you've had one sprain you're very
likely to have another balance training
is important because it improves the
coordination of the muscles that support
the ankle
so we start with the short foot exercise
this exercise stabilizes the many bones
of the foot providing a stable base of
support for balanced training exercises
with the foot flat on the ground the
ball of the big toe is pushed into the
floor and then pulled back towards the
heel the muscles in the arch of the foot
should be contracted to pull the big toe
towards the heel it's important to keep
the toes straight and not curled up
during this exercise so that only the
muscles in the arch are used to cause
the movement the leg that she wants to
work is gonna be the leg that she stands
out and you have her look up as she does
that and just focus on a point on the
wall to make it harder what we can do is
we can adjust the arm position so we can
have her take her arms and put them
across the chest and we can also take
vision away and now we're gonna rely
more on the information that's coming
from the ankle joint itself in order to
maintain balance next what we're gonna
do is we're gonna add an unstable
surface underneath the foot so this is
just about a two inch thick foam pad
we're gonna set right here so again
she's gonna start off with her arms at
her side and with her eyes open once
she's really comfortable doing that that
we can change the arm position and then
we can take vision away as well so we
want to start the exercises for about 10
seconds at a time and then just
gradually make them longer and longer as
you get better if your foot touches down
that's fine just start going again the
next group of exercises we're going to

then you're just going to pull the

the exact same way we can change the arm

you want to do is do that nice and slow
so that it really forces you to keep
your balance on the foot that's on the
